title: Symptoms:
content:
Depressed mood most of the day, nearly every day
Loss of interest or pleasure in most activities
Significant weight changes or appetite disturbance
Sleep disturbances (insomnia or excessive sleeping)
Fatigue or loss of energy
Feelings of worthlessness or excessive guilt
Difficulty concentrating or making decisions
Thoughts of death or suicidal ideation
Causes and Risk Factors:
Postnatal depression can result from a combination of biological, psychological, and social factors, including History of depression, hormonal changes, sleep deprivation, stress, lack of support, previous mental health conditions and difficult birth experience (complications during delivery)
Treatment options:
Psychotherapy: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT), Interpersonal Therapy (IPT)
Medication: Antidepressants (e.g., SSRIs, under medical supervision)
Support networks: Seeking help from family, friends, or support groups
Self-care: Prioritizing rest, nutrition, exercise, and relaxation techniques
3.Anxiety disorder

title: Definition
content:
The term anxiety is used to describe feelings of uncertainty, uneasiness, apprehension, or tension that a person experiences in response to an unknown object or situation.
Fear versus Anxiety
Anxiety is an alerting signal or response to a threat that is unknown, internal, vague, or conflictual.
Fear is a similar alerting signal but should be differentiated from anxiety by its response to a known, external, definite, non-conflictual threat.
Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD)

title: Definition
content:
DSM-5 defines Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD) as excessive anxiety and worry about various aspects of daily life, occurring more days than not for at least six months.
A. Excessive anxiety and worry (apprehensive expectation) occurring more days than not for at least six months, about a number of events or activities (such as work, school, or personal matters).
B. The individual finds it difficult to control the worry.
C. The anxiety and worry are associated with three (or more) of the following six symptoms (with at least some symptoms present for more days than not in the past six months): (Only one item is required in children.)
Restlessness or feeling keyed up or on edge
Being easily fatigued
Difficulty concentrating or mind going blank

title: Irritability
content:
Muscle tension
Sleep disturbance (difficulty falling or staying asleep, or restless, unsatisfying sleep)
D. The anxiety, worry, or physical symptoms cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.
E. The disturbance is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance (e.g., drug abuse, medication) or another medical condition (e.g., hyperthyroidism).
F. The disturbance is not better explained by another mental disorder, such as panic disorder, social anxiety disorder, obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD), or post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD).
Causes of Generalized Anxiety Disorder
Generalized Anxiety Disorder can be caused by many factors, including genetics, hormones, stress/trauma, substance abuse, physical illness, and economic or psychological stress.
Treatment options for GAD

title: Pharmacotherapy
content:
The decision to prescribe anxiolytic to patients with GAD should rarely be made on the first visit because of the long-term nature disorder
The three major drugs for treatment of GAD are:
Benzodiazepines-drugs of choice
(SSRIs),
Buspirone (buspar) and venlafaxine
Other drugs that may be useful are:
TCAs(e.g.imipramine)
Adrenergic antagonists (propranolol)
Duration of treatment 6-12 month, some study indicates that treatment should be long term, perhaps lifelong.
About 25% of pts relapse in the first month after discontinuation of therapy and 60-80% relapse over the course of the next year

title: Psychotherapy
content:
The major psychotherapeutic approaches is:
Cognitive-behavioral,
Supportive, and
Insight oriented

title: Lifestyle Changes:
content: Regular exercise, mindfulness, stress management techniques.
